thread.title: What's on this weekend

author: Telegraph Travel
title: What's on this weekend
text: Weather forecast Friday will see both sunshine and cloud across the UK, with highs ranging between 15 and 17C. Saturday will be more overcast in England but brighter in Scotland, and a degree warmer in most places. Sunday will see a little more sun breaking through again. Great Cornish Food Festival, Truro More than 40,000 people flocked to Truro’s three-day event last year, and they can do so once again when the Great Cornish Food Festival returns in September. The festival is a chance to enjoy pop-up restaurants, masterclasses and moreish delights from more than 60 local producers. greatcornishfood.co.uk Food and Drink Festival, Rugby Celebrate all that is great about food and drink originating from and around the home and birthplace of the game, with a special Rugby World Cup theme . Rugby has a Fan Zone – giant screens, food, drink, the works – set up in the Old Market Place on match days. On non-match days, from September 12-November 6, the zone becomes Rugby Village, with a varied programme of events. enjoyrugby.co.uk . • Rugby: how to visit the town where the game began The town's surprisingly small Rugby Museum Birmingham Weekender The Birmingham Weekender showcases music, dance, theatre, art, literature, food, and fashion across the city centre. Embracing both local and international artists, there will be dance performances on rooftop carparks, and an orchestra of bell-ringing across the city. The event will take place during the Rugby World Cup, where Birmingham is also a host city, and dance inspired by the famous Haka alongside an introduction to ballet will appear in Centenary Square. visitbirmingham.com Raindance Film Festival Britain’s biggest independent film festival , and Europe’s largest, continues this weekend, showcasing 100 feature films and more than 150 short films from “independent, new and alternative” filmmakers around the world. Popular films that have previously premiered at the festival include Memento, Old Boy and The Blair Witch Project. Guy Pearce in the film Memento, which premiered at the Raindance Film Festival Photo: Alamy Write on Kew The inaugural literary festival at Kew Gardens features more than 80 book-related events across various genres, including fiction, science, gardening, cookery and children’s literature. Visitors can enjoy talks and presentations from some of Britain’s most celebrated authors and literary experts, including Michael Morpurgo (War Horse), Bill Bryson (A Walk in the Woods), Louis de Bernières (Captain Corelli's Mandolin), Ella Woodward (Deliciously Ella cookery books), and David Nicolls (One Day and Us), as well as Andrew Marr, chef Raymond Blanc and the actor Richard E Grant. • 7 things you never knew about Kew Gardens Experience Life Life is Anton Corbijn's low-key portrait of James Dean, starring Robert Pattinson and out in cinemas this weekend. Thoughtfully scripted by Luke Davies, the film understands Dean’s fame as the moment something changed, not just the birth of a new type of movie icon, but the idea of a reluctant celebrity willing to parade his vulnerabilities. Read Telegraph critic Tim Robey's full four-star review. Coast and Country Walking Festival, Sussex More than 60 organised walks will be on offer this autumn across Sussex at the Coast and Country Walking Festival. As well as walks, the annual festival will include wild forest food foraging, navigation techniques, and wine tasting. It will also celebrate the notorious Sussex builder Mad Jack Fuller, with a quirky free tour around the follies he created. sussexwalkingfestival.org.uk • The best coastal walks in the UK London Design Festival Intended to promote the city as the design capital of the world and to celebrate the wealth of creative talent based here, the London Design Festival , which organisers say is one of the best yet, concludes this weekend. A plethora of events throughout the city cater handsomely to most tastes, but some stand out more than others: highlights of the 2015 programme include the opening of a multi-sensory and futuristic department store at the Old Selfridges Hotel, multiple special events, installations and exhibitions at festival hub The V&A, and a showcase of winners of the British Land Celebration of Design Awards at Somerset House. British Ceramics Biennial, Stoke-on-Trent The British Ceramics Biennial will feature 20 exhibitions with over 60 national and international ceramic artists in numerous venues across Stoke's ‘potteries’. There will be activities and special events as well as opportunities to purchase the exhibition pieces. One highlight will be a new WW1 commemorative installation in honour of the fallen men of the North Staffordshire regiment. britishceramicsbiennial.com • What to do in London this weekend Telegraphtravel Follow @telegraphtravel
